newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - AMEC shares rise on 71 pct profit jump.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - AMEC shares rise on 71 pct profit jump.

text.p: British engineering and construction group AMEC Plc cheered investors on Thursday with a 71 percent rise in 1996 pretax profits and a one third hike in its dividend payout.

Pretax profits for 1996 rose to 27.2 million pounds ($44.3 million) from 15.9 million after taking a 10.5 million one-off charge. Stripping out exceptional charges, profits were 37.7 million against 24.7 million in 1995.
The dividend was raised to four pence a share from three in 1995, while sales swelled to 2.77 billion from 2.45 billion.

"It's pleasing to announce pretax profits up 71 percent accompanied by further improvements in the group's cash position and a dividend increased by 33 percent," AMEC chief executive Peter Mason said.
"This level of increase demonstrates our confidence going forward," he said. Net cash was up more than threefold to 63.4 million.
The market welcomed the news, pushing AMEC shares up 14-1/2 pence to 141-1/2 before it edged back.
"The results were pretty encouraging and the shares have reacted accordingly," one market-maker said.
AMEC said its internal review was continuing and that further progress would be made this year.
Mason told Reuters he planned more small disposals in the current year, but declined to comment further.
He said there were signs of an uptick in British construction. The building and civil engineering division saw a positive performance last year in the U.S., with progress in British road projects.

Germany remained a difficult market, but Mason said it accounted for just three percent of turnover at 100 million pounds. A return to profitability in Germany was not envisaged until the market improves, despite cost cutting measures.

The mechanical and electrical unit saw a 17 percent rise in profit assisted by a contribution from the new AMEC Rail division. Process and energy returned to profit but AMEC said there was still further scope for improvement.
Housing saw a 13 percent rise in sales and operating margins up six percent. While the services business performed well across all divisions and remains an area for expansion.

The company said the May 1 British election had led to a delay in a number of private finance initiative (PFI) health projects under which the private sector will build infrastructure for public health services.
AMEC has been announced as preferred bidder for several PFI deals.

The 1996 exceptional charge related to a 25 million write-off for the housing division, a 2.7 million charge for German restructuring and 2.3 million write-off against investments which were partly offset by disposal gains of 19.5 million. ($ = 0.614 British Pounds)
